Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Seeing the invisible: Locating hydrogen atoms in protein crystal structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Protein enzymes are the amazing catalysts, essential for the existence of living systems. They are also used extensively in biotechnology industry. They dramatically increase reaction rates, are exquisitely specific and they function in water. The ability to harness enzymes for use in the chemical industry would be a major advance. Unfortunately, one of the most important components of proteins, their hydrogen atoms, are invisible. The long-term goal of the proposed work is to solve this problem and make the location of hydrogen atoms more accessible to researchers. The results will advance efforts to design new catalysts by enzyme engineering. To support the adoption of methods to be developed, a public web server to process user submitted data will be implemented. Additionally, the project strengthens collaborations and training opportunities between the University of Hawaii and world-class facilities at the Department of Energy. The project will also provide new curriculum, outreach and student research opportunities that are integrated in the research plan. Special emphasis is placed on supporting Native Hawaiian and minority STEM students in collaboration with campus student support programs. A new research project-based undergraduate protein biochemistry course will be developed. Student work on expressing, purifying, and crystallizing different ferredoxin mutants add to the research efforts. Ng will serve as a mentor and speaker to minority STEM support programs, conduct outreach activities at local high schools through the Crystal Growing Challenge and train teachers to lead students to explore conditions that maximize the growth of ferredoxin crystals.

The research uses novel experimental and computational methods to attain its goal of identify and locating hydrogen atoms in protein structures by applying the proposed computational approach, HyPO (Hydrogen Prediction and Observation) to X-ray and neutron diffraction data. Traditionally, crystallographers determine whether an atom is present in a crystal structure by visual comparison with a contoured electron density map. HyPO takes a fundamentally different, quantitative approach by answering the question: What arrangement of atoms is most probable given a map? The combination of HyPO and powerful new neutron sources at collaborating Oak Ridge National Laboratory will make neutron crystallography more accessible to structural biologists. HyPO will be used to analyze ferredoxin, a key enzyme in photosynthesis whose hydrogen atoms have never been directly observed. HyPO analysis will be applied to the determination of neutron structures of ferredoxin to define how ferredoxin transfers electrons. New insight into the role of hydrogen atoms in ferredoxin will have important applications in other electron transfer proteins and to protein in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our work has achieved the following scientific goals:

1. We were successful in our original goal of developing a computational method of identifying hydrogen atoms from data generated by X-ray crystallography. Experimental identification of hydrogen atoms provides new data that can supplement or improve results from traditional computation prediction. Locating these hydrogen atoms has provided new insights into how important enzymes work. They can also improve the results of calculations used for computer-aided drug design. We presented the results in multiple national scientific meetings. They will also be published in multiple upcoming publications.

2. Our experience working on this project has expanded our interest in developing and applying computational methods for analyzing protein structures. One important computational method we have been using is molecular dynamics simulations. Molecular dynamics simulations use classical equations of physics to calculate the motions of atoms in biomolecules. We have been applying this method to better understand fluorescent proteins and drug receptor proteins. Fluorescent proteins are heavily used in cutting edge microscopy experiments to light up specific proteins of interest. We have worked with leading research groups around the world to develop high-performance fluorescent proteins and fluorescent biosensors. Our work has been published in multiple papers in leading scientific journals. We have found structural and dynamic properties that are partially responsible for improved brightness of fluorescent proteins that will improve microscopy performance. Our lab has also performed experimental work, primarily X-ray crystallography, to validate the results from our computations.

3. Our lab has also developed a new major research focus on applying artificial intelligence computation to biochemistry problems, especially in how predicting drug binding and designing new drug molecules. These important problems represent major challenges for fundamental chemistry regarding how molecules recognize each other. We published our first paper on applications of machine learning to drug activity prediction. We placed fourth in the Drug Design Data Resource competition for predicting drug activities using our artificial intelligence methods.

 

Our work has achieved the following broader impacts:

1. Over the years, this project has directly involved eight graduate students, three postdoctoral fellows, and eleven undergraduate students. This project is unusual in its interdisciplinary scope and provides excellent training for students. Support from the NSF helped our lab become the largest research lab on our former campus at the University of Hawaii, the first-choice lab for the top graduate and undergraduate students. Graduates from our lab have moved on to attend top PhD programs, medical school, and jobs with leading scientific companies. Our lab was the largest producer of medical students in Hawaii. We also had two students win the top prize at University of Hawaii undergraduate research symposiums. Many of our undergraduates published research papers.

2. Our outreach work involved hundreds of students from Hawaii high schools. Students from a local, low income high school report it has increased their interest in attending college and studying science. For many, it was their first time at a college campus. Undergraduate and graduate students from our lab shared their stories of overcoming adversity. It also provided good training experiences for the graduate students in our lab interested in a teaching career. Two of our undergraduate students have graduated to attend PhD programs in synthetic biology and pharmacology.

3. Dr. Ng continues to champion student diversity. The PI's lab at the University of Hawaii was >50% women in a department that historically had a poor representation of women students. Present and recent lab members include native Hawaiians, Latinos, veterans, and nontraditional students. A former Latino graduate student joined a leading computational chemistry software company after graduating. We graduated one of the very few native Hawaiian PhD scientists this year. He is pursuing a career in college teaching with a focus on serving minority and underserved students. Currently, the lab includes three Latino and one non-traditional woman student interested in health care careers.
